newsitem.title: FRANCE: BoF head happy with low May French inflation.
newsitem.headline: BoF head happy with low May French inflation.

text.p: Official figures showing weak French inflation won praise on Friday from Bank of France Governor Jean-Claude Trichet who said it was one of the conditions for low interest rates.

"Confirmation of a weak rise in prices is...one of the necessary conditions to permit our medium- and long-term rates to be kept at a remarkably low level, the third lowest in the world and the lowest in the European Union, along with Dutch and German rates," he told Reuters in a telephone interview.
The preliminary data released on Friday by national statistics institute INSEE showed a month-on-month rise in May of 0.2 percent and a year-on-year rise of 0.9 percent.
"This good result conforms to the objectives of the Monetary Policy Council (of the Bank of France) for 1997," Trichet said.

Trichet said last December that the central bank's goal was a price increase cap of two percent for 1997 and the medium term. The low inflation "would help preserve the purchasing power of households," he said.
The latest figures meant that, "France today ranks among the three countries in the European Union performing best in terms of inflation," Trichet said.
He noted that the average year-on-year inflation rate in the European Union in April stood at 1.5 percent.
